Pete, I also have several ( about 6 I think ) Toshow magazines that have 
3=
 or 4 page speads on Nobuiye and mei. It is all in Japanese but the 
images=
 are clear. They covered ( in the magazines ) Nobuiye and Kaneiye.

If you =
like, I can scan them up and PDF them you you. Not sure if they 
will help.=


Rich

Jim Gilbert wrote:

>Pete,
>I can't think of anything in English be=
tter than the Tsuba Geijutsu-Ko by Toigoye and Haynes.  I'm sure that there=
 is further commentary in Joly's translations of Akiyama republished in the=
 NCJSC newsletters some years ago, but I don't have them organized or index=
ed.
>
>Nobuie Tsuba by Nakamura is as good a picture sources as any, at lea=
st for having large numbers of examples to compare.  Each mei is attributed=
 to a type in the text of the oshigata section.  The attribution is usually=
 at or near the end of the text (lower left portion).  
>=E6=94=BE=E3=82=8C=
=E9=8A=98 hanare-mei, =E5=A4=AA=E5=AD=97=E9=8A=98 futoji- mei, =E8=A9=B0=E3=
=82=8A=E9=8A=98 sumari-mei, =E5=B7=A6=E5=82=BE=E9=8A=98 sakei-mei and =E7=
=94=B2=E8=83=83=E9=8A=98 katchu-mei are ones I saw frequently when I flippe=
d through the book.  
>
>In the past there were something like 8 or more ca=
tegories of mei in use.  Most signatures these days are lumped into futoji-=
mei and hanare-mei.  There's quite a bit of variability among accepted exam=
ples in each category though, so things are still not simple.  Wakayama sho=
ws some details about the different signatures in the first volume of his T=
oso Kodogu Koza.  No doubt there are other comparisons in the various surve=
y books.
>
>It's a difficult area.
>
>Jim
>
>  
>
